Good Morning <!group>. Katie here with the Admin team. Letting you all know that at the end of this week, we will be discontinuing this channel. Please be sure to collect one another’s contact information. As well as staying in touch Jack (<mailto:jack.bennetto@galvanize.com|jack.bennetto@galvanize.com>) & Amara (<mailto:amara.willson@galvanize.com|amara.willson@galvanize.com>). Hope to see you on campus again soon. Best! :galvanize:

Thanks again for the attending the class! Feel free to reach out in the future on slack, at <https://www.linkedin.com/in/jackbennetto>, or at <mailto:jack.bennetto@galvanize.com|jack.bennetto@galvanize.com>
Great class with you all! I would love to keep in touch! <http://linkedin.com/in/reddingcharles>
I also will be in the 3rd Floor classroom before the info session between 6 and 6:30 if you do want to stop by and ask me any last minute questions

If you have any other questions please feel free to reach out to me at <mailto:amara.wilson@galvanize.com|amara.wilson@galvanize.com>, it's been great having you all on campus and we hope to keep seeing you around Galvanize!

It's time for another survey! *Please* fill this out before class (or after or during if you don't get a chance): <https://docs.google.com/a/galvanize.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdB0X0Q52RjJuV2rvUuzqZ29u8yzArZ9PMmQFoMNg5qnSOQMw/viewform>

It definitely helps to think about what’s happening at each step. Using your example:

`x = info[1]` sets `x` equal to `(3, 4)`
`x[0]` returns `3`

So, it makes tons of sense that `info[1][0]` returns `3` as well. It’s just combining two steps (look up `info[1]`, and then find index `[0]` of what it returns) into one line.

NM! Got this from StackOverflow if anyone is interested

In the majority of programming languages when you need to access a nested data type (such as arrays, lists, or tuples), you append the brackets to get to the innermost item. The first bracket gives you the location of the tuple in your list. The second bracket gives you the location of the item in the tuple.

This is a quick rudimentary example that I came up with:

info = [ ( 1, 2), (3, 4), (5, 6) ]

info[0][0] == 1
info[0][1] == 2
info[1][0] == 3
info[1][1] == 4
info[2][0] == 5
info[2][1] == 6
is this calling two indices at one time in a list? Just a bit confused here
Can someone help me figure out this piece of code? if self.board[y][x] in [' X ', ' O ']:

For an example of well-written code, take a look at <https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn> (warning: this is huge library and it's not that easy to understand, particularly since we haven't used it in class yet)

userinput = raw_input('Please put a state name: ')
userinput1 = userinput.capitalize()
print userinput1
state_dictionary = {'Colorado': 'Denver', 'Alaska': 'Juneau', 'California': 'Sacramento',
                        'Georgia': 'Atlanta', 'Kansas': 'Topeka', 'Nebraska': 'Lincoln',
                        'Oregon': 'Salem', 'Texas': 'Austin', 'New York': 'Albany'}
state_dictionary.get(userinput1, 'Capital unknown')
<@U2JPPK543>  for the question 2-2
(In other words: you are correct in thinking that putting the parentheses on line 7 is weird. Where do they really belong?)

<@U2JPPK543> In response to your question above:

The parentheses are what tell Python to *call* the function instead of just returning the function itself.

Try this in iPython:
```In [1]: user_input = raw_input('What State capital are you looking for?').capitalize
What State capital are you looking for?foo

In [2]: user_input
Out[2]: <function capitalize>

In [3]: type(user_input)
Out[3]: builtin_function_or_method

In [4]: user_input()
Out[4]: ‘Foo’```

As you can see, `user_input` is being set to a `function` when you probably meant for it to be a `str`.

How would you fix this in your code?

Most good text editors, when you put the cursor on a parenthesis, will highlight the *matching* parenthesis.  This is very useful for diagnosing this kind of thing (which is very common, even for experienced programmers)

<@U2JPPK543> Here:
```
user_coord = tuple(user_query.split(', ‘)
```
You’re missing a closing parenthesis.

Tonight’s class will be in the 2nd-floor classroom. Really, this time it will. :slightly_smiling_face:

Unfortunately, we haven’t really done list comprehensions yet so the solutions might not help (or sets, which we’ll do tonight). You can also use the `in` operator: `x in lst` will return True if x is an element of lst and False if it isn’t.
The solutions at all available at <https://github.com/zipfian/solns-python-fundamentals-seattle2>
2) More tricky, if you have a list L, then list(set(L)) removes duplicates from the list.
1) create a list already_seen = [].  Then as you scan through elements, check if they are in the list using an if statement, and only add them when they have not been seen before.
There are two options here.

Then when I update the solutions with each day’s assignments, you can copy down the changes with (this is a new git command you haven’t learned yet!) ```git pull```
(ordinarily you Fork the repo on github first, but here you don’t need to since you won’t be changing anything)

If you’d like to copy them on your own computer, just do
```git clone <https://github.com/zipfian/solns-python-fundamentals-seattle2>```
